In Mark 14:50, the disciples scattered and abandoned Jesus in his time of need. This is evident from the various versions, such as the Vulgate Latin, Syriac, Arabic, Persic, and Ethiopic, which all describe the disciples forsaking him. It is important to note that this refers specifically to the disciples, and not to the larger crowd that Jesus was addressing at the time. The disciples' desertion highlights the challenging and lonely path that Jesus was about to embark on, as he faced his crucifixion.

In the midst of Jesus' hour of great trial, the disciples, as stated by the various versions, forsook and fled from him. This desertion was exclusive to the disciples, not the multitude that surrounded Jesus. The disciples' abandonment magnifies the difficult and solitary road that lay ahead of Jesus as he prepared to face his crucifixion.
